div1.p:
The Missouri girl who insisted on being
married in her native State believes in
starting right.--St. Louis Republic.

Yes; “the happy pair” doubtless started
for New York directly after the ceremony.

A Chicago paper says
THINK IT OVER. that when an Arizona
man comes to New York
now he must feel that he is a good deal of
a tenderfoot. What would he feel like if
he stopped over in the Windy City?

The Yellow Fever Situation in Cien-
fuegos.

The appearance of yellow fever among
the military hospital corps in Cienfuegos
tells the oft repeated story of neglected
sanitary precautions by the local author-
ities, and of the unrecognized first case
that spread the pest. Although only nine
cases have thus far been reported, it is
evidently too early to say that the situa-
tion is under absolute control.

Of course, every effort is now being
made, even by the dilatory local officials,
to aid our military authorities in stamp-
ing out the fever by isolating the patients,
killing the stegomyia mosquito and clean-
ing up outlying districts. Evidently a
great deal of work is necessary in the
latter direction, as Cienfuegos has for a
long time been in a very bad sanitary
condition.

When the causes of yellow fever propa-
gation are so well known and the whole
problem rests upon the extermination of
a particular infecting insect the very
simplicity of the solution of that problem
adds to the gravity of the neglect of such
a plain sanitary duty.

The HERALD'S Cuban sanitary commis-
sion, after a thorough inspection of the
West Indies in the winter of 1904. pointed
out the necessity of preventive measures
in such direction, and much good has
come from its efforts since then, but that
all is not yet as it should be is evident
enough by the appearance of small out-
breaks at longer or shorter intervals. We
must not only kill the stegomyia persist-
ently, but make it eventually impossible
for it to propagate. This can only be
done by the abolition of stagnant pools
and garbage heaps and by the drainage
of swamps and the establishment of a
proper sewage system.

As was pointed out by the HERALD
commission, a prime necessity is a gen-
eral cleaning up of all filthy districts.
Perhaps the situation around Cienfuegos
will be a sufficient object lesson to the
natives to awaken them to the present
urgent necessities of the occasion and
properly stimulate them to aid our mili-
tary authorities in every way in their
power.
